An Administrative Problem

We advertise in order that the public may better
understand what the Bell System is doing, and why it
does it. In this way we keep customers and prospective
customers informed of our aims,policies and progress.
We advertise in order to aid the telephone customer
in making the best possible use of his service. As our
advertising influences one person after another to use
the telephone more effectively, the service rendered
every other user is correspondingly improved.
We advertise because we have a varied service to
sell and by selling more of it we increase its value to
each user. Because of the nature of the telephone
business, it is our duty to inform the public continuously of the character and varied kind of service we
provide.

This is the first of a series of
biographical sketches of those at
the helm of the new intramural
athletic program. Sketches of
Frank Dotterweich, Ed Lotz,
Gardner Malonee, Dr. Kelso Morrill, Paul Kaiss, Gus Van Sant,
Bill Logan, George Darley, Waldo Hambleton, Reuben Baer and
Bobby Owings will follow.

All Linemen On Jay Team
Except Halibert, Center, Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, director
Are Veteran Performers the extensive intramural program
The Blue Jays swoop down on
Ohio Field, New York City, tomorrow for the inaugural tussel of the
campaign against Dr. Mal Stevens'
New York University Violets.
Dr. Ray Van Orman, Jay mentor,
is anxious to see his men—especially
the newcomers—disport under fire,
and will, in all likelihood alternate
two elevens. The first combination
will tip the scales at about 170 on
the line and 1r3 in the backfield,
yielding to f. C.lothamites a weight
advantage of annosi 25 pounds.
Jay Lineup Listed
In Billy Van Orman and Pasarew,
the Jays have two vets on the ends.
Carter and Orth, also vets, will fill
the tackle berths, with Giardini and
Phillips at the guards. Halibert will
cavort at center. The backfield will
have McClean, at quarterback, barking signals; Merson and Vincenti, at
the halves; and Kelly, fullback.
Galloway, Rhode, Bishop, McGuire,
Novak, Ellis, Leberfeld and Bergman will relieve the starting forwards from time to time. Houck,
Lankford, Graziano and Zerilli will
get a chance to show their worth in
the backfield.
Violets Average 185
New York U.'s line packs 190
pounds from end to end, and the balltoters are not much lighter, their
mean weight being around the 185
mark. The Violets' huskies are De
Benedictis and Walz, co-captains and
tackles, who carry 210 and 208
pounds with them; Klein, a 202
pound end; and Smith a 202 pound
back.
Last year the Violets trounced
Carnegie Tech and Lafayette, tied
Rutgers, and lost to Foraham by
only one touchdown.
Tomorrow's tilt will mark the first
meeting of the Jays and Violets
the gridiron, Lehigh invades Homewood to open the home campaign a
week from tomorrow.

of
of
athletics at the Johns Hopkins, was
born in nineteen hundred and two.
From his earliest days athletics have
held a high place in all of his activities.
At the early age of fourteen Dr.
Shaffer accepted an offer to play baseball for the New Bedford team of the
New England League. The decision
cost the doctor his amateur status as
an athlete and resulted in his loss of
the opportunity to play high school
and college baseball.
The year 1917 found Dr. Shaffer
starring in the Eastern Professional
Basketball League. He continued to
play "pro ball" right through until
1922. In 1919 he succeeded in holding
down a place on a professional football team. Since then Dr. Shaffer
has been most active in coaching and
refereeing amateur athletics, not confining his efforts to any one particular sport, but in all sports.
The Playground Athletic League
has found in Dr. Shaffer a most conscientious worker, and he has served
that body as assistant director. At
City College he has coached soccer
and track.
Dr. Shaffer received his A.B. degree from Hopkins in 1924 and in
1928 was honored with the degree of
doctor of philosophy In addition to
his work in athletics he will lecture
in psychology in place of Dr. Roy
Dorcus, who has been granted a leave
of absence from the University.

Terps In For Battle
The heavy Maryland team that defeated St. Johns last week is expected to meet somewhat of a snag
when it opposes Washington and Lee
this Saturday. This squad, the dark
horse of the Southern Conference last
year, is laying in wait for the Terps
to avenge a 33-13 trouncing in
1933. The Generals can match Maryland in weight, and their coach has
succeeded in turning out a formidable aggregation.

Cannonade Begins In Big Ten
As Minnesota Strives To
Humble Michigan

Coast Teams Strong
Pitt, Cornell, And Princeton
Make It Hard To Pick The
East's Leading Team
Will the Gophers of Minnesota topple Michigan from the Big Ten throne
they have occupied the last four
years? Can Southern California recapture her position at the top of the
Far West gridirons?
Will October and November nominate Pitt or Princeton, Fordham or
Cornell, the Army or Navy as leader
of the East? Who will it be in the

Despite the scarcity of tried hands
at Purdue, Noble Kizer's Boilermakers must be labeled tough because
of the availability of Duane Purvis
and Jim Carter, a pair of versatile,
high-voltage backs; Ed Skoronsi, a
stubborn center; and a crate of promising sophs.
Illinois, more potent
than usual, Ohio State, and Iowa are
conceded an outside chance of upsetting the favorites and crashing into
the top rankings.
Battle On Coast
Conditions on the Pacific Coast do
not suggest the early abdication of
Claude Thornhill's Stanford eleven
and the return of Southern California
to power. The Trojans' spell was
snapped last fall by an Oregon State
tie and a Stanford defeat.
Their
strength sapped considerably by the
absence of thirteen lettermen, the
Trojans, to again become number one
team in the Golden West, must plow
through a Stanford squad effected
very little by the graduation toll. The
Indians miss but three men, and retain their backfield intact. This allows for a cast of capable reserves, inasmuch as few second-stringers are
advancing to the regular fold.

Inaugurating cross-country practice on the opening day of the school
year, Coach Hambleton already has
his candidates working hard in preparation for the opening meet of the
year.
Led by Captain Holtzman, who has
made a sterling record in both crosscountry and track for the last three
years, the harriers give promise of
making an excellent showing in dual
competition this season. As a running mate, Holtzman will have Carl
Sholtes, a sophomore who made the
varsity track team in his freshman
year.
Other veterans from previous seasons are Clark and Kirkman, both experienced performers. In addition to
these, there are several junior varsity
runners from last year as well as
some promising newcomers that will
bolster the squad considerably.

With the new stream-lined football and several rule changes, a season of wide-open football and high
scores appears in store for the fans.
Forward passing will be used more
than ever before with the new-sized
ball, which will permit more players
to take part in the passing attack.
In the past years, a thrown ball
which fell into the end zone was a
touchback and became the possession of the defending team on its 20yard line. This fall, however, it will
remain in the possession of the attacking team, thereby giving it another chance to score, especially if
it is seeking to score from within
the 20-yard line.

Entry Blanks For Interclass
Soccer Tourney Placed In
Postoffice Boxes
Entries for the interclass soccer
tournament, the first activity on Dr.
G. Wilson Shaffer's sports-for-all
program, have been placed in the
mailboxes. Students are requested to
return the blanks to Box 236 not later
than Monday noon.
Practice is scheduled to get under
way within a week. The schedule for
next week's practice is seniors, Monday; the juniors on Tuesdays; the
sophomores, Wednesday; and the
freshmen, Friday.
All Urged To Play
Urging all those whose schedules
allow to back the intramural card
from the start, the tourney heads
said, "The purpose of this activity is
not to develop material varsity
teams or, to teach the game. It is
merely to give every individual a
chance to participate in athletics and
benefit physically from it—and the
free, natural motions involved in
soccer makes the sport ideal for our
Purpose."
Competition will begin definitely
before the third week of the month.
The leaders of the tourney intend to
open with round robin tests, and then
to arrange a league including the
champions of the respective classes.
If sufficient interest still perists,
contests between the Engineers, Arts
and Sciences students and other departments "le:9,1,1 be arranged.

teams of five men, with five substitutes will play on a eld fty feet by
forty, with six by six goals, and an
eight foot crease. The goals will be
blocked with wooden screens except
for a space around the edges, top and
upper corners, corresponding to the
vital spots around the goalkeeper in
regulation play. In other ways the
game, though faster, will be played
according to national rules.

Kaiss promised individual attention

An Administrative Problem

We advertise in order that the public may better
understand what the Bell System is doing, and why it
does it. In this way we keep customers and prospective
customers informed of our aims,policies and progress.
We advertise in order to aid the telephone customer
in making the best possible use of his service. As our
advertising influences one person after another to use
the telephone more effectively, the service rendered
every other user is correspondingly improved.
We advertise because we have a varied service to
sell and by selling more of it we increase its value to
each user. Because of the nature of the telephone
business, it is our duty to inform the public continuously of the character and varied kind of service we
provide.

This is the first of a series of
biographical sketches of those at
the helm of the new intramural
athletic program. Sketches of
Frank Dotterweich, Ed Lotz,
Gardner Malonee, Dr. Kelso Morrill, Paul Kaiss, Gus Van Sant,
Bill Logan, George Darley, Waldo Hambleton, Reuben Baer and
Bobby Owings will follow.

All Linemen On Jay Team
Except Halibert, Center, Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, director
Are Veteran Performers the extensive intramural program
The Blue Jays swoop down on
Ohio Field, New York City, tomorrow for the inaugural tussel of the
campaign against Dr. Mal Stevens'
New York University Violets.
Dr. Ray Van Orman, Jay mentor,
is anxious to see his men—especially
the newcomers—disport under fire,
and will, in all likelihood alternate
two elevens. The first combination
will tip the scales at about 170 on
the line and 1r3 in the backfield,
yielding to f. C.lothamites a weight
advantage of annosi 25 pounds.
Jay Lineup Listed
In Billy Van Orman and Pasarew,
the Jays have two vets on the ends.
Carter and Orth, also vets, will fill
the tackle berths, with Giardini and
Phillips at the guards. Halibert will
cavort at center. The backfield will
have McClean, at quarterback, barking signals; Merson and Vincenti, at
the halves; and Kelly, fullback.
Galloway, Rhode, Bishop, McGuire,
Novak, Ellis, Leberfeld and Bergman will relieve the starting forwards from time to time. Houck,
Lankford, Graziano and Zerilli will
get a chance to show their worth in
the backfield.
Violets Average 185
New York U.'s line packs 190
pounds from end to end, and the balltoters are not much lighter, their
mean weight being around the 185
mark. The Violets' huskies are De
Benedictis and Walz, co-captains and
tackles, who carry 210 and 208
pounds with them; Klein, a 202
pound end; and Smith a 202 pound
back.
Last year the Violets trounced
Carnegie Tech and Lafayette, tied
Rutgers, and lost to Foraham by
only one touchdown.
Tomorrow's tilt will mark the first
meeting of the Jays and Violets
the gridiron, Lehigh invades Homewood to open the home campaign a
week from tomorrow.

of
of
athletics at the Johns Hopkins, was
born in nineteen hundred and two.
From his earliest days athletics have
held a high place in all of his activities.
At the early age of fourteen Dr.
Shaffer accepted an offer to play baseball for the New Bedford team of the
New England League. The decision
cost the doctor his amateur status as
an athlete and resulted in his loss of
the opportunity to play high school
and college baseball.
The year 1917 found Dr. Shaffer
starring in the Eastern Professional
Basketball League. He continued to
play "pro ball" right through until
1922. In 1919 he succeeded in holding
down a place on a professional football team. Since then Dr. Shaffer
has been most active in coaching and
refereeing amateur athletics, not confining his efforts to any one particular sport, but in all sports.
The Playground Athletic League
has found in Dr. Shaffer a most conscientious worker, and he has served
that body as assistant director. At
City College he has coached soccer
and track.
Dr. Shaffer received his A.B. degree from Hopkins in 1924 and in
1928 was honored with the degree of
doctor of philosophy In addition to
his work in athletics he will lecture
in psychology in place of Dr. Roy
Dorcus, who has been granted a leave
of absence from the University.

Terps In For Battle
The heavy Maryland team that defeated St. Johns last week is expected to meet somewhat of a snag
when it opposes Washington and Lee
this Saturday. This squad, the dark
horse of the Southern Conference last
year, is laying in wait for the Terps
to avenge a 33-13 trouncing in
1933. The Generals can match Maryland in weight, and their coach has
succeeded in turning out a formidable aggregation.

Cannonade Begins In Big Ten
As Minnesota Strives To
Humble Michigan

Coast Teams Strong
Pitt, Cornell, And Princeton
Make It Hard To Pick The
East's Leading Team
Will the Gophers of Minnesota topple Michigan from the Big Ten throne
they have occupied the last four
years? Can Southern California recapture her position at the top of the
Far West gridirons?
Will October and November nominate Pitt or Princeton, Fordham or
Cornell, the Army or Navy as leader
of the East? Who will it be in the

Despite the scarcity of tried hands
at Purdue, Noble Kizer's Boilermakers must be labeled tough because
of the availability of Duane Purvis
and Jim Carter, a pair of versatile,
high-voltage backs; Ed Skoronsi, a
stubborn center; and a crate of promising sophs.
Illinois, more potent
than usual, Ohio State, and Iowa are
conceded an outside chance of upsetting the favorites and crashing into
the top rankings.
Battle On Coast
Conditions on the Pacific Coast do
not suggest the early abdication of
Claude Thornhill's Stanford eleven
and the return of Southern California
to power. The Trojans' spell was
snapped last fall by an Oregon State
tie and a Stanford defeat.
Their
strength sapped considerably by the
absence of thirteen lettermen, the
Trojans, to again become number one
team in the Golden West, must plow
through a Stanford squad effected
very little by the graduation toll. The
Indians miss but three men, and retain their backfield intact. This allows for a cast of capable reserves, inasmuch as few second-stringers are
advancing to the regular fold.

Inaugurating cross-country practice on the opening day of the school
year, Coach Hambleton already has
his candidates working hard in preparation for the opening meet of the
year.
Led by Captain Holtzman, who has
made a sterling record in both crosscountry and track for the last three
years, the harriers give promise of
making an excellent showing in dual
competition this season. As a running mate, Holtzman will have Carl
Sholtes, a sophomore who made the
varsity track team in his freshman
year.
Other veterans from previous seasons are Clark and Kirkman, both experienced performers. In addition to
these, there are several junior varsity
runners from last year as well as
some promising newcomers that will
bolster the squad considerably.

With the new stream-lined football and several rule changes, a season of wide-open football and high
scores appears in store for the fans.
Forward passing will be used more
than ever before with the new-sized
ball, which will permit more players
to take part in the passing attack.
In the past years, a thrown ball
which fell into the end zone was a
touchback and became the possession of the defending team on its 20yard line. This fall, however, it will
remain in the possession of the attacking team, thereby giving it another chance to score, especially if
it is seeking to score from within
the 20-yard line.

Entry Blanks For Interclass
Soccer Tourney Placed In
Postoffice Boxes
Entries for the interclass soccer
tournament, the first activity on Dr.
G. Wilson Shaffer's sports-for-all
program, have been placed in the
mailboxes. Students are requested to
return the blanks to Box 236 not later
than Monday noon.
Practice is scheduled to get under
way within a week. The schedule for
next week's practice is seniors, Monday; the juniors on Tuesdays; the
sophomores, Wednesday; and the
freshmen, Friday.
All Urged To Play
Urging all those whose schedules
allow to back the intramural card
from the start, the tourney heads
said, "The purpose of this activity is
not to develop material varsity
teams or, to teach the game. It is
merely to give every individual a
chance to participate in athletics and
benefit physically from it—and the
free, natural motions involved in
soccer makes the sport ideal for our
Purpose."
Competition will begin definitely
before the third week of the month.
The leaders of the tourney intend to
open with round robin tests, and then
to arrange a league including the
champions of the respective classes.
If sufficient interest still perists,
contests between the Engineers, Arts
and Sciences students and other departments "le:9,1,1 be arranged.

In concluding, the physical director
asserted that the plan of giving each
man experience and instruction in every sport was sure to produce teams
fit for intercollegiate competition.
Wrestling coaches from other colleges,
he said, are eager for bouts not only
for their first team, but also for the
second and third strings.
Gardner Malonee described the modified intramural lacrosse competition;
teams of five men, with five substitutes will play on a eld fty feet by
forty, with six by six goals, and an
eight foot crease. The goals will be
blocked with wooden screens except
for a space around the edges, top and
upper corners, corresponding to the
vital spots around the goalkeeper in
regulation play. In other ways the
game, though faster, will be played
according to national rules.
Ed Lotz, George Darley, and Paul
Kaiss promised individual attention
and a chance for all, regardless of experience, in every sport as it comes
in season.
